<@U2D637AKY> Have you tried using the actual local IP of the server instead of localhost? Localhost is for your local machine (i.e. the machine that is making the call), so you need to get the local IP of the server instead and point to that
and how do you get the ip of your server if i may ask? <@U1LJG0Y03>
<@U1LJG0Y03> you get the most important point!
I’m assuming that your work machine is also acting as your server?
yes, because am hosting my project on my localhost in WAMp
Open command prompt by pressing `win + R` and typing `cmd`
Your machine’s IP address is the one under `IPv4 Address`
that’s what i use as replacement for the `<http://localhost>` url
Then in your app just append it so it looks something like `<http://192.168.4.29>`
Also note that when you restart your computer, or reconnect to the wifi, this address may change unless you configure your router to always give you the same local IP

hey guys, I was reading about ORM for Android and saw a few comments telling "Why not use ORM for Android", one of them tells something about interface components who need a cursor to be filled, so using the ORM this become unusable, somebody knows something about this?
POJOs are usually sufficient for most things
Otherwise, ORMs are fine depending on use case
I think most people use <http://realm.io|realm.io> these days
Could be wrong, but that’s what I’ve noticed more than anything else
I saw this Realm when I was reading about ORM
Yeah, the main bonus to it is it’s classes just look like POJOs
So it’s easy to implement, and easy to use
Statements like `realm.where(User.class).equalTo(“userId’, 1).findFirst();` make it quite simple to access data
It also works well with things like RxJava and Retrofit
yeah, understood, I think this could be what I looking for
I'm personally not a fan of ORMs such as ormlite as they clutter up your POJOs and become too coupled.
Haven't tried Realm yet since last time I looked, it didn't support inheritance.  Has that changed?
but what you suggested, plain SQL?
